title: 112_hr5050
content: The Act titled "Social Networking Online Protection Act" prohibits employer access to personal accounts on social networking websites. The "Social Networking Online Protection Act" prohibits employers from requiring employees to provide access to private email or social media accounts and from taking adverse actions against employees who refuse to do so. The "Social Networking Online Protection Act" prohibits employers from accessing employees' social media accounts or taking adverse actions against them for not providing access. Employers who violate this Act may face civil penalties of up to $10,000, taking into account their compliance history and the severity of the violation. The "Social Networking Online Protection Act" prohibits employers from accessing employees' social media accounts or taking adverse actions against them for not providing access. Civil penalties for violations can be up to $10,000, based on compliance history and severity of the violation. The Secretary of Labor can take injunctive actions to restrain violations and ensure compliance with the Act. Penalties are collected in a similar manner as specified in the Migrant and Seasonal Agricultural Worker Protection Act. The Act allows for legal or equitable relief, such as reinstatement, promotion, and payment of lost wages and benefits, to ensure compliance. SEC. 3. INSTITUTION OF HIGHER EDUCATION ACCESS TO PERSONAL ACCOUNTS ON SOCIAL NETWORKING WEBSITES. Section 487(a) of the Higher Education Act of 1965 is amended to prohibit institutions from requesting access to students' private email or social media accounts. The Higher Education Act of 1965 prohibits institutions from requesting access to students' private email or social media accounts if the student refuses or has filed a complaint related to this provision. The Higher Education Act of 1965 prohibits institutions from accessing students' social media accounts if the student refuses or is involved in a legal proceeding. The term "social networking website" is defined in the Social Networking Online Protection Act. SEC. 9537 prohibits local educational agencies from accessing students' personal accounts on social networking websites. Local educational agencies cannot require students to provide access to private email or social media accounts, and they cannot take adverse actions against students who refuse to do so. The provision prohibits educational agencies from accessing students' social media accounts or taking action against students who refuse to provide access. SEC. 5. DEFINITIONS. The term "employer" refers to any person acting in the interest of an employer in relation to an employee or applicant for employment. The term "social networking website" is defined as an Internet service that provides a user with a distinct account for uploading, storing, and managing personal content.
